title: Haleakalā National Park: The Military during WWII in the Park
body: Explore This Park    Learn About the Park     History & Culture     Stories     The Military during WWII in the Park                The Military during WWII in the Park                   Red Hill military installation               Red Hill military installation               Red Hill military installation               Red Hill military installation               Red Hill military installation               Pu'u Nianiau base camp               Pu'u Nianiau base camp               Pu'u Nianiau base camp          The Haleakalā Section of Hawai'i National Park was used by the military from 1941-1948.  The summit of Haleakalā (Red Hill) was the site of various installations; the first, a fixed radar station associated with the Aircraft Warning Service system.  The Army also built a base camp for personnel stationed at the Summit on a six-acre site near Pu'u Nianiau.  The Puʻu Nianiau base camp was turned over to the NPS in 1946.  Red Hill was returned to the NPS in 1948; however, the dilapidated military buildings and antennae were not removed until 1961.   For more information please select Hawai'i, the Military, and the National Park: World War II and Its Impacts on Culture and the Environment (501 pages/ 31.96 MB).
